content.description: Start at the bottom of a right leaning flake.  Climb this to more jugs up and right.  Jugs the whole way to a crux mantle (the top out was covered in ice when I climbed this, so it may be more straight forward than I thought)
content.location: West end of Peary Boulder about 10' left (North) of obvious arete

content.description: Sit start right of the obvious flake on two good slopers. Pull on and move left to the flake. Follow the obvious path of good holds to the lip and figure out the final moves to the top.
content.location: Around the corner from Standard Overhang on the Peary Boulder.

content.description: A fun eliminate. Start sitting just right of the easy flake route on the southern face on two slopey but good holds. Move up to nasty sloper pockets at 5-6' before hitting a pair of positive edges that lead to better holds above. A v1 variation uses the flake and skips the sloper moves, instead moving from the flake to the edges.
content.location: About the center of the southern (downhill) face of the boulder, about 1 foot right of the obvious well chalked flake.

content.description: This line follows the left edge of the triangular roof on the right end of the boulder, traversing right to the roof's point (where the downhill face meets the uphill face). The holds are comfortable and the moves enjoyable and consistent, which more than make up for the fact that it's a lowball traverse.
content.location: Follow the trail along the southern (downhill) face of the boulder to the right end, where the trail heads uphill and a 3-4' high roof forms. Here, a very large, left trending flake meets the roof's left end (a v1, Laid Back, climbs that flake).  The route begins at a jug under the roof at this flake and heads out the roof before traversing right and heading up the arete to top out.

content.description: The largest boulder below the main formation of Jockey Cap, the Peary Boulder hosts a variety of climbs from v0 to open projects, and also has several established traverses along its southern (downhill) face.
